title: Isaiah Chapter 58 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 58 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 58 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 58.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:1, how should the voice be lifted when showing the people their transgression?
questions.correctAnswer: Like a trumpet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:1 commands to lift up the voice like a trumpet to show the people their transgression.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:2, how does the nation described seek God?
questions.correctAnswer: Daily
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:2 states that they seek God daily and delight to know His ways.

questions.question: What question do they ask in Isaiah 58:3 regarding fasting?
options: Why do You not see our fasting?
questions.correctAnswer: Why do You not see our fasting?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:3 shows they ask, 'Wherefore have we fasted, and thou seest not?'.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 58:4 says people fast for strife and debate to be heard on high.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:4 states that they fast for strife and debate and to make their voice heard on high.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:5, is bowing down the head like a bulrush and spreading sackcloth and ashes the fast God has chosen?
options: No, it is not the fast God has chosen
Yes, it is the fast God has chosen
God has not spoken about this
questions.correctAnswer: No, it is not the fast God has chosen
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:5 questions if such outward affliction is the fast God chose, implying it is not.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 58:6: 'Is not this the fast that I have chosen? to loose the bands of _______, to undo the heavy burdens...'
questions.correctAnswer: wickedness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:6 states the fast God chose is to loose the bands of wickedness.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:7, what should you do when you see the naked?
questions.correctAnswer: Cover him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:7 commands to cover the naked and not hide from your own flesh.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 58:8 says that after the right fast, your light will break forth as the morning.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:8 promises that the light will break forth as the morning after doing the right fast.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:9, what will the LORD do when you call?
options: He shall answer and say, Here I am
questions.correctAnswer: He shall answer and say, Here I am
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:9 states that when you call, the LORD will answer, saying, 'Here I am.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:10, what happens if you satisfy the afflicted soul?
options: Your light will rise in obscurity
questions.correctAnswer: Your light will rise in obscurity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:10 says that if you satisfy the afflicted soul, your light will rise in obscurity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:11, how does the LORD describe the person He guides?
options: Like a watered garden and a spring of water
questions.correctAnswer: Like a watered garden and a spring of water
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:11 describes the guided person as like a watered garden and a spring whose waters do not fail.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 58:12 says they shall raise up the foundations of many generations.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:12 says they shall raise the foundations of many generations.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:13, what should you turn away from on the sabbath?
questions.correctAnswer: Doing thy pleasure
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:13 encourages turning away from doing your own pleasure on the sabbath.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 58:14: 'Then shalt thou delight thyself in the _______, and I will cause thee to ride upon the high places of the earth.'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:14 states that delighting in the LORD will cause you to ride upon the high places of the earth.

questions.question: What title will you be called according to Isaiah 58:12 after rebuilding old waste places?
questions.correctAnswer: The repairer of the breach
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:12 says you shall be called The repairer of the breach, the restorer of paths to dwell in.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 58 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 58 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58 teach us about the true purpose of fasting in Christian life?
options: To humble oneself and break every yoke of oppression
To fast for strife and debate
To make one's voice heard on high by complaining
To bow down with sackcloth and ashes
questions.correctAnswer: To humble oneself and break every yoke of oppression
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:6-7 explains that the fast God chooses is to loose the bands of wickedness, undo burdens, let the oppressed go free, and care for the hungry and naked, contrasting with fasting for strife or mere outward humility (verses 4-5).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58, what should Christians do when they see the poor and naked?
options: Bring them into their house and cover them
Ignore them and continue their fast
Call the elders to judge them
questions.correctAnswer: Bring them into their house and cover them
questions.explanation: Verse 7 instructs believers to deal bread to the hungry, bring the poor into their homes, cover the naked, and not hide from their own flesh, teaching practical generosity and care.

questions.question: What promise does Isaiah 58 give to those who practice true fasting and generosity?
options: Their light will break forth as the morning and health will spring forth speedily
They will be wealthy and powerful
They will be free from all troubles instantly
They will be honored by all nations
questions.correctAnswer: Their light will break forth as the morning and health will spring forth speedily
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:8 promises that true fasting and righteous acts will result in light breaking forth, swift health, righteousness going before them, and the glory of the LORD as their reward.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58 describe God's response to a believer who calls on Him after removing oppression and false speech?
options: God will answer, saying 'Here I am'
questions.correctAnswer: God will answer, saying 'Here I am'
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says that when a person removes the yoke and speaking vanity, God will respond to their calls with 'Here I am,' showing His readiness to help the obedient.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 58 say about the effect of satisfying the afflicted soul and helping the hungry?
options: Their light will rise in darkness and their darkness will be as the noonday
They will be ignored by others
They will have no change in their life
questions.correctAnswer: Their light will rise in darkness and their darkness will be as the noonday
questions.explanation: Verse 10 teaches that drawing out the soul to the hungry and satisfying the afflicted results in light rising in darkness and darkness becoming like noonday, symbolizing joy and clarity.

questions.question: What guidance and blessings does the Lord promise to those who live according to Isaiah 58's teachings?
options: Continuous guidance, satisfaction in drought, and being like a watered garden
questions.correctAnswer: Continuous guidance, satisfaction in drought, and being like a watered garden
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:11 promises that the LORD will guide continually, satisfy the soul even in drought, make bones strong, and liken the believer to a watered garden whose waters fail not.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58, what role will those who follow God's ways have in restoring their community?
options: They will be called the repairer of the breach and restorer of paths to dwell in
They will be judges over others
They will receive honor only for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They will be called the repairer of the breach and restorer of paths to dwell in
questions.explanation: Verse 12 describes that faithful people will rebuild waste places, raise foundations, and be known as repairers and restorers, highlighting service and restoration.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58 instruct believers to regard the Sabbath day?
options: As a delight and holy day to honor the Lord
As a day to do their own pleasure
As a day to speak their own words
questions.correctAnswer: As a delight and holy day to honor the Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 13 teaches that the Sabbath should be honored by turning away from personal pleasures and honoring God, calling it a delight and a holy day.

questions.question: What promise is given to those who delight themselves in the Lord according to Isaiah 58?
options: They will ride upon the high places of the earth and be fed with the heritage of Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: They will ride upon the high places of the earth and be fed with the heritage of Jacob
questions.explanation: Verse 14 promises that those who delight in the Lord will be exalted and fed with the heritage of Jacob, symbolizing blessing and provision.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fasting that feels empty and unfruitful. Based on Isaiah 58, what biblical truth would you share about proper fasting?
options: True fasting involves acts of justice, freeing the oppressed, and helping the needy
Fasting is mainly about outward signs like sackcloth and ashes
Fasting should be done to gain attention from men
Fasting is not important in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: True fasting involves acts of justice, freeing the oppressed, and helping the needy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:5-7 clarifies that the fast God chooses is not merely afflicting oneself but actively loosening bonds of wickedness, undoing burdens, freeing the oppressed, and providing for the poor and naked.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58 guide believers regarding their speech and attitudes towards others?
options: Remove the yoke, stop pointing fingers, and avoid speaking vanity
Speak boldly to expose others' faults
Focus only on personal spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Remove the yoke, stop pointing fingers, and avoid speaking vanity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:9 encourages believers to remove burdens, stop accusing others, and avoid speaking empty words, fostering humility and reconciliation.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 58 teaches that one can fast and yet continue to engage in strife and wickedness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 4 clearly states that fasting while engaging in strife and wickedness is not acceptable to God, showing that fasting must be accompanied by righteous behavior.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 58 encourages believers to find delight in God's holy day and refrain from pursuing their own pleasures on the Sabbath.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 13 instructs believers to turn away from their own ways and pleasures on the Sabbath and call it a delight, honoring the Lord on His holy day.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 58 teaches that God’s chosen fast is to ______ the bands of wickedness and let the oppressed go free.
questions.correctAnswer: loose
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:6 states that the fast God chooses is to loose the bands of wickedness, highlighting liberation and justice as key aspects of true fasting.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 58 say about those who seek God daily and delight to know His ways?
options: They seek God as a nation that did righteousness and did not forsake His ordinances
They seek God occasionally and forget His commandments
They seek God only when in trouble
They seek God with insincere hearts
questions.correctAnswer: They seek God as a nation that did righteousness and did not forsake His ordinances
questions.explanation: Verse 2 describes people who seek God daily and delight to know His ways as a nation that practiced righteousness and did not forsake the ordinances of God.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 58 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 58.

questions.question: In Isaiah 58:6, the fast chosen by the LORD is described as an act to:
options: bow down the head as a bulrush
questions.correctAnswer: loose the bands of wickedness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:6 explains that the fast God chooses is to 'loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens, and to let the oppressed go free,' highlighting social justice rather than mere ritual.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:1, the prophet is commanded to lift his voice like a trumpet to:
questions.correctAnswer: show the people their transgression
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:1 directs the prophet to 'lift up thy voice like a trumpet, and shew my people their transgression,' emphasizing prophetic rebuke and correction.

questions.question: What is the primary criticism in Isaiah 58:3 regarding the people's fasting?
options: They fast to find pleasure and exact all their labours
They fast with genuine humility and repentance
They fast by giving to the poor
They fast to honor the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: They fast to find pleasure and exact all their labours
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:3 criticizes the people for fasting while still finding pleasure in their daily labors and oppressing others, indicating insincerity in their fasting.

questions.question: In the literary structure of Isaiah 58, the phrase 'the glory of the LORD shall be thy rereward' (verse 8) functions as:
options: a historical reference to past events
a legal injunction to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: a climactic promise following obedience
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:8 serves as a key poetic climax promising divine blessing and glory as a result of righteous actions, fitting the chapter's chiastic and prophetic structure.

questions.question: The Hebrew term translated as 'afflict his soul' in Isaiah 58:5 is significant because it:
questions.correctAnswer: denotes fasting and self-denial
questions.explanation: The phrase 'afflict his soul' in Isaiah 58:5 is a Hebrew idiom for fasting or self-denial, critical to understanding the ritualistic fasting criticized in this chapter.

questions.question: Isaiah 58:7 emphasizes social justice by instructing to:
options: deal thy bread to the hungry and cover the naked
offer daily sacrifices at the temple
questions.correctAnswer: deal thy bread to the hungry and cover the naked
questions.explanation: Verse 7 highlights acts of mercy and charity—feeding the hungry and clothing the naked—as true fasting pleasing to God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:11, the LORD's guidance results in the soul being:
questions.correctAnswer: satisfied even in drought
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:11 uses agricultural imagery to depict the soul as nourished and strong despite hardship, illustrating divine provision.

questions.question: Isaiah 58:13 connects honoring the sabbath with:
questions.correctAnswer: turning away from personal pleasure
questions.explanation: Verse 13 instructs to 'call the sabbath a delight' by refraining from doing one's own ways or seeking personal pleasure, emphasizing holiness and reverence.

questions.question: The phrase 'The repairer of the breach, The restorer of paths to dwell in' (Isaiah 58:12) alludes to:
options: restoration of Israel's social and spiritual order
questions.correctAnswer: restoration of Israel's social and spiritual order
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:12 metaphorically describes repairing broken social relationships and restoring communal stability, not only physical rebuilding.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 58:4, fasting is acceptable when it is done with strife and debate.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:4 explicitly condemns fasting done in strife and debate, indicating such fasting is not acceptable to God.

questions.question: In Isaiah 58:9, God promises to answer when His people:
options: take away the yoke and speaking vanity
questions.correctAnswer: take away the yoke and speaking vanity
questions.explanation: Verse 9 links God's promise to answer with the removal of oppression ('yoke') and vain speech, emphasizing ethical reform.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the emphasis on fasting that leads to social justice as described in Isaiah 58?
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 6:16-18
questions.explanation: Matthew 6:16-18 addresses the attitude in fasting, emphasizing sincerity over public display, which aligns with Isaiah 58's critique of empty ritual fasting.

questions.question: The contrast in Isaiah 58 between ritual fasting and ethical fasting is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: parallelism
questions.explanation: The chapter frequently uses parallelism contrasting external ritual with internal ethical behavior, a common Hebrew poetic device, as seen in verses 3-7.

questions.question: The cultural context of fasting criticized in Isaiah 58 likely involved:
questions.correctAnswer: ritual observance without justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58 condemns fasting that is mere ritual without accompanying justice and mercy, reflecting ancient Near Eastern religious practices where ritual often lacked ethical concern.

questions.question: Isaiah 58:10 metaphorically describes light rising in obscurity and darkness as noonday to illustrate:
options: the transformative power of acts of mercy
questions.correctAnswer: the transformative power of acts of mercy
questions.explanation: Verse 10 uses light imagery to symbolize how compassionate actions bring clarity and blessing even in difficult circumstances, a theme developed across Scripture.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 58 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 58 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason God commands to 'Cry aloud, spare not, lift up thy voice like a trumpet' in Isaiah 58:1?
options: To reveal the people's transgressions and sins
To call the people to worship
To declare God's judgment on nations
questions.correctAnswer: To reveal the people's transgressions and sins
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:1 commands to loudly proclaim the people's sins and transgressions. This is consistent with prophetic calls in Ezekiel 33:7-8 and Jeremiah 6:17 where the prophet is commanded to warn the people about their sins. Jesus also emphasized calling out sin in John 8:44, and Paul exhorted the church to correct sin in Galatians 6:1.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:2, how do the people describe themselves in relation to God?
options: As a nation that did righteousness and did not forsake God's ordinance
As a nation that rejects God’s law
As a people who desire only material blessings
As a people who have forgotten God
questions.correctAnswer: As a nation that did righteousness and did not forsake God's ordinance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:2 shows the people claiming they seek God daily and delight in His ways, describing themselves as righteous and obedient. This self-perception contrasts with their actual behavior, similar to the Pharisees in Matthew 23:28 and Israel's hypocrisy exposed in Amos 5:21-24. The New Testament also warns against mere outward religion in James 1:26-27.

questions.question: In Isaiah 58:3, what complaint do the people raise about their fasting?
options: They fast but God seems not to notice
questions.correctAnswer: They fast but God seems not to notice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:3 records the people's complaint that their fasting is unseen by God. This reflects a misunderstanding of fasting's purpose, similar to the warnings in Matthew 6:16-18 and Zechariah 7:5-6, where fasting without true repentance and justice is rejected by God. True fasting is about heart transformation (Joel 2:12-13).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:5, what does God say about the kind of fasting the people practice?
options: It is not the fast God has chosen
It is a fast pleasing to God
It is a fast that brings blessings
It is a fast commanded by God
questions.correctAnswer: It is not the fast God has chosen
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:5 emphasizes that the outward affliction and ritual fasting the people practice is not the fasting God desires. This aligns with God's rejection of empty ritual in Hosea 6:6, Micah 6:6-8, and Jesus' teaching that mercy is better than sacrifice (Matthew 9:13). Genuine fasting involves justice and mercy.

questions.question: What kind of fast does God choose according to Isaiah 58:6?
options: To loose the bands of wickedness and let the oppressed go free
To afflict the soul with sackcloth and ashes
To refrain from eating for a full day
To isolate oneself from the community
questions.correctAnswer: To loose the bands of wickedness and let the oppressed go free
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:6 describes the fast God desires as one that breaks oppression and injustice. This aligns with God's heart for justice in Psalm 82:3-4, Proverbs 31:8-9, and Jesus’ mission to proclaim freedom for the oppressed in Luke 4:18. The fast is a call to active righteousness and liberation.

questions.question: What acts of compassion are included in the fast described in Isaiah 58:7?
options: Sharing bread with the hungry and clothing the naked
Keeping the Sabbath and praying daily
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing bread with the hungry and clothing the naked
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:7 states that true fasting involves feeding the hungry, housing the homeless, and clothing the naked. This reflects God’s concern for the needy throughout Scripture, such as in Deuteronomy 15:11, Matthew 25:35-40, and James 2:15-16. Genuine worship is inseparable from compassionate deeds.

questions.question: What is the promised outcome when the people practice the fast God chooses, according to Isaiah 58:8?
options: Their light will break forth like the morning
Their enemies will be destroyed immediately
They will receive wealth and power
They will be hidden from all troubles
questions.correctAnswer: Their light will break forth like the morning
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:8 promises that practicing God's chosen fast leads to a bright, renewing light like morning. This metaphor for divine blessing and righteousness is found in Psalm 37:6, Proverbs 4:18, and the New Testament’s description of Christ as the Light of the world in John 8:12 and 2 Corinthians 4:6.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:9, what must be removed to receive God’s answer and presence?
options: The yoke, pointing the finger, and speaking vanity
questions.correctAnswer: The yoke, pointing the finger, and speaking vanity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:9 teaches that to call upon God effectively, one must remove oppression (the yoke), judgmental attitudes (finger pointing), and empty speech (vanity). This is consistent with Micah 6:8’s call for justice, mercy, and humility, as well as Jesus’ teaching on judging others in Matthew 7:1-5 and the importance of truthful speech in Ephesians 4:25.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 58:10 teach about the blessings for those who satisfy the afflicted soul and feed the hungry?
options: Their light will rise in darkness and their darkness be as the noonday
They will be given riches and honor
They will never face hardship again
They will be exalted above all nations
questions.correctAnswer: Their light will rise in darkness and their darkness be as the noonday
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:10 reveals that acts of mercy bring spiritual illumination even in difficult times. This theme appears in Psalm 112:4, John 1:5, and Matthew 5:14-16, where believers' good works shine as a light in darkness, reflecting God's glory and guidance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58:11 describe God's ongoing care for those who follow His ways?
options: God will guide continually and satisfy their soul even in drought
God will give them great armies
God will make them rulers over nations
God will hide them from all afflictions
questions.correctAnswer: God will guide continually and satisfy their soul even in drought
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:11 promises God's continual guidance and provision even in difficult times, like a watered garden. This is echoed in Psalm 23:2-3, Isaiah 40:11, and John 10:27-28, where God as Shepherd leads, sustains, and strengthens His people.

questions.question: What future restorative work is promised in Isaiah 58:12 for those who follow God's ways?
options: They will rebuild old waste places and be called repairers of the breach
They will establish a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: They will rebuild old waste places and be called repairers of the breach
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:12 speaks of restoration and renewal, with God's people rebuilding ruins and restoring paths. This imagery parallels Nehemiah 2:17-18, Ezekiel 34:11-16's promise of restoration, and the New Testament church's role in spiritual restoration (Ephesians 2:19-22). It highlights God’s redemptive work through His people.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 58:13, what attitude should believers have toward the Sabbath?
options: They should call it a delight and honor the holy day
They should treat it as an ordinary day
They should use it for personal pleasure
They should avoid any work, even acts of mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They should call it a delight and honor the holy day
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:13 commands believers to joyfully observe the Sabbath as holy and honorable, not for selfish pleasure. This reflects God's design in Exodus 20:8-11 and Jesus’ teaching in Mark 2:27 that the Sabbath is made for man’s benefit and delight. True Sabbath observance is worshipful and restorative.

questions.question: What is the promised blessing in Isaiah 58:14 for those who honor the Sabbath as God commands?
options: They will delight in the LORD and be fed with the heritage of Jacob
They will live without any sorrow
They will become kings and priests
They will receive immediate earthly prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: They will delight in the LORD and be fed with the heritage of Jacob
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58:14 promises delight in God and inheritance from Jacob for honoring the Sabbath. This echoes God's covenantal blessings to Israel in Genesis 28:13-15 and Deuteronomy 33:4-5. Jesus also points to true rest in Him (Matthew 11:28-30), fulfilling Sabbath rest for believers.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 58 teach about the nature of true righteousness and salvation?
options: It involves justice, mercy, and liberation rather than mere ritual fasting
It depends solely on external religious observance
It requires strict adherence to dietary laws
It is achieved by isolating oneself from society
questions.correctAnswer: It involves justice, mercy, and liberation rather than mere ritual fasting
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58 contrasts hollow rituals with authentic righteousness expressed in justice and mercy (Isaiah 58:6-7). This aligns with Micah 6:8, Hosea 6:6, and Jesus' teaching in Matthew 23:23 that true salvation involves loving God and neighbor, not empty ceremonies. Salvation is holistic transformation.

questions.question: What attribute of God is especially revealed in Isaiah 58 through His response to fasting and justice?
options: God is just and desires mercy over sacrifice
God values ritual above all else
God is indifferent to human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God is just and desires mercy over sacrifice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 58 reveals God’s justice and mercy, rejecting mere ritual fasting without compassion (58:5-7). This matches God's nature shown in Psalm 85:10, Hosea 6:6, and reiterated by Jesus (Matthew 9:13) and James (James 1:27). God’s holiness demands both justice and mercy as expressions of true worship.
